author: T Madhavan
text:
2 wards have not been integrated with main sewage network: residents

It is nearly five years since Madipakkam was merged with the Chennai Corporation, which, residents say, is why they are baffled that the locality is yet to have underground drainage network.

Residents of wards 187 and 188 complain that these areas are yet to be integrated with the main sewage network.

N. Subramanian of Karthikeyapuram said residents had raised this issue at every forum they have access to. He said that when Madipakkam was a village panchayat in 2009, a consultation report was submitted for a Comprehensive UGD project at a cost of Rs. 30.59 crore, which had to be dropped for want of funds.

In an RTI application filed by him, he was informed that land acquisition to build sewage pumping stations in Madipakkam was on. A Detailed Project Report (DPR) for the UGD scheme for Madipakkam would be taken up and after getting funds from the government, tenders would be called for civil works, the reply said. There had been no progress since then, Mr. Subramanian said.

“Madipakkam, a village panchayat with a population of over 70,000 and part of St. Thomas Mount Panchayat Union, was merged with the Corporation in 2011. While the surrounding areas such as Ullagaram and Puzhuthivakkam got the underground drainage network, it is still a mystery why these two wards (187 and 188) have been left out,” said N. Balasundraram, another resident, who was part of a delegation that represented their grievances to the Mayor in 2014 and 2015.

Members of civic groups said sewage lorry operators charged exorbitant amounts to clear sewage from septic tanks.

in 2011
title: 5 years on, Madipakkam yet to get underground drainage
